content: Singaporean neurologist (1955–2024) **Lee Wei Ling** (7 January 1955 – 9 October 2024) was a Singaporean [neurologist](/wiki/Neurologist). She was the director of the [National Neuroscience Institute](/wiki/National_Neuroscience_Institute). A prominent member of the [Lee family](/wiki/Lee_family_(Singapore)), she was the younger sister of [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong), the older sister of [Lee Hsien Yang](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Yang) and the only daughter of [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew), the founding prime minister of Singapore. ## Early life and career Lee was born on 7 January 1955. She received a [President's Scholarship](/wiki/President%27s_Scholarship) in 1973, before studying in the medical faculty of the [University of Singapore](/wiki/University_of_Singapore) (now the [National University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore)), where she graduated top of her class with a [Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Medicine_and_Bachelor_of_Surgery) degree before specialising in [pediatrics](/wiki/Pediatrics). She began working in the pediatric ward at the [Singapore General Hospital](/wiki/Singapore_General_Hospital) (SGH) and received board certification from the American Board of Clinical Neuropsychology. ## Personal life Lee Wei Ling was the daughter of [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew) and [Kwa Geok Choo](/wiki/Kwa_Geok_Choo). She was the younger sister of [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong) and the older sister of [Lee Hsien Yang](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Yang). Wei Ling enjoyed driving and admitted to [speeding](/wiki/Speed_limit) on a visit to [New Hampshire](/wiki/New_Hampshire) in 1995; she was pulled over by highway police but was released by the sympathetic officer after discussing the [caning of Michael Fay](/wiki/Caning_of_Michael_Fay). In 2015, shortly after the death of her father, Lee Wei Ling published an autobiographical book, *A Hakka Woman's Singapore*, based on columns that she had previously written. She publicly spoke against [hero worship](/wiki/Cult_of_personality) of the founding Prime Minister. In 2016, an editor at *[The Straits Times](/wiki/The_Straits_Times)* accused Lee of plagiarism in an unpublished article. Lee publicly supported [freedom of speech](/wiki/Freedom_of_speech) and stated that she would cease writing for the newspaper following the editorial dispute. In 2022, Lee Wei Ling reportedly sold a property worth S$50 million to Yonghong Shi, a cofounder of [Haidilao](/wiki/Haidilao). ### Administrator of Lee Kuan Yew's will Lee Wei Ling and her brother, [Lee Hsien Yang](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Yang), were the joint administrators and executors of Lee Kuan Yew's will. However, they were in a dispute in 2017 with [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong) over their late father's will with regard to the house at [38 Oxley Road](/wiki/38_Oxley_Road). They "felt threatened by Lee Hsien Loong's misuse of his position and influence over the Singapore government and its agencies to drive his personal agenda". They alleged that Hsien Loong used his father's legacy to improve Hsien Loong's reputation and that he thwarted the will of their father in order to use the house at 38 Oxley Road as a monument to their father, which was something that their father allegedly did not want. They also criticised the influence of [Ho Ching](/wiki/Ho_Ching) over the government, and alleged that the Prime Minister harboured political ambitions for his son, Li Hongyi. A special parliamentary session was held to clear the Prime Minister of any wrongdoings and the siblings agreed to keep the dispute private after the session. ### Illness and death In August 2020, Lee Wei Ling stated on a [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook) post that she had been diagnosed with [progressive supranuclear palsy](/wiki/Progressive_supranuclear_palsy), a rare brain disorder that results in the weakening of certain muscles. Lee was known for her [stoicism](/wiki/Stoicism) and stated that she would "endure" in the face of her condition. Lee died at her home on 9 October 2024, at the age of 69. Her body was cremated at [Mandai Crematorium](/wiki/Mandai_Crematorium), and her ashes were scattered in sea off Scotland. ## Publications - Lee, Wei Ling; Yap, Koon Hong (2016). *A Hakka woman's Singapore stories: my life as a daughter, doctor, and diehard Singaporean*. Singapore: Straits Times Press. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 978-981-4642-47-7.
